qas.question: Which central European country had a Calvinist ruler?
After Huguenots fled France, their last remaining bastion was where?
What did the 18th century Huguenot group call themselves?
Against whom did the Camisards rise up to fight?

answers.text: the Catholic Church in the region
the Catholic Church in the region

qas.question: French troops put down the Camisard uprisings between what years?
In what year did Frederick William of Prussia become the Great Elector?
How many Huguenots fled to England?
How many people did Prussia lose due to war?
When did the fighting stop in Prussia?
In what year did the Camisards organize as a regional group in southern France?

context: After this, Huguenots (with estimates ranging from <b6_0>200,000<b6_0/> to <b7_0>1,000,000<b7_0/>) fled to surrounding Protestant countries: England, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Norway, Denmark, and <a0_0><a0_2>Prussia<a0_2/><a0_0/> — whose Calvinist <a0_1>Great Elector Frederick William<a0_1/> welcomed them to help rebuild his war-ravaged and underpopulated country. Following this exodus, Huguenots remained in large numbers in only one region of France: the rugged <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Cévennes<a1_1/><a1_0/> region in the south<a1_2/>. In the early 18th century, a regional group known as <a2_2>the <a2_0><a2_1>Camisards<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> who were Huguenots rioted against <a3_0><a3_2>the <a3_1>Catholic Church<a3_1/> in the region<a3_2/><a3_0/>, burning churches and killing clergy. It took French troops years to hunt down and destroy all the bands of Camisards, between <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b5_0><b8_0><b9_0>1702<b9_0/><b8_0/><b5_0/> and 1709<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
